author: John Cross
title: Arsene Wenger determined to stay on and rebuild Arsenal despite prospect of losing Alexis Sanchez and Mesut Ozil
text:
Sport Arsene Wenger determined to stay on and rebuild Arsenal despite prospect of losing Alexis Sanchez and Mesut Ozil The Gunners boss is ready to sign a new two-year deal and believes he can rediscover his glory years Share Wenger has promised to clarify his future soon (Photo: Copyright Unknown)   Thank you for subscribing!   
Arsene Wenger needs to become Arsenal’s version of the Six Million Dollar Man this summer. 
“We have the technology, we can rebuild him,” was the catchphrase from the 1970s TV show about Colonel Steve Austin needing bionic implants to gain superhuman strength. 
Wenger is ready to reinvent himself in order to rebuild Arsenal and his own reputation, and bring back success to the Emirates. That’s the deal and the reasoning behind the discussions over a new two-year contract. 
Make no mistake. Wenger has made his decision clear that he wants to stay and, even at 67 and after years of stubbornness, he believes he can rediscover his glory years. 
There will be a major shake-up of the squad, big changes behind the scenes - they want a new Academy director and in the longer term a director of football - and an expectation of Wenger being able to take the club “to the next level.” Wenger believes he can bring back the glory days (Photo: Stuart MacFarlane) 
That has become the buzz phrase around the place despite the prospect of losing star duo Alexis Sanchez and Mesut Ozil this summer. 
If they will not sign new deals, then they will be sold and subconsciously Wenger is already having to plan without them which has been telling in dropping Sanchez at Liverpool while Ozil’s drop in form has been a cause of growing frustration. 
But the sudden change in strategy around Wenger’s future has been revealing, with a belief that some of the backroom staff could be told this week about the Frenchman committing himself to a new deal. Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Arsene Wenger speaks after Arsenal lose 3-1 at West Brom Share this video Watch Next 
A few weeks back, there was a growing belief that Wenger could go but he has made it clear he wants to stay, he commands the respect in the boardroom and, most tellingly, with majority shareholder Stan Kroenke. 
If there is a major rebuilding job to be done then they would rather trust it to the man they know - even if they know that will not be a universally popular decision. 
Arsenal insist that no final decision has been taken, it will be mutual but the fact they were so quick to deny reports of an approach for Borussia Dortmund’s Thomas Tuchel was illuminating in its own way. 
Tuchel was among their list of potential replacements but they did not want the story in any way to cloud the issue that they are moving towards Wenger staying for another two years. Tuchel has been linked with the Arsenal job (Photo: Alexandre Simoes) 
It is also interesting that the timing of Wenger staying comes at the start of an international break. Do your worst, be angry, go into meltdown and it may have subsided a little by the time Arsenal next play - against Manchester City on Sunday week - and Wenger next faces the media. 
That is another factor in the decision. Arsenal need to be sure that Wenger can rebuild and succeed despite the stale atmosphere of disaffection. 
Planes flying banners overhead at the Hawthorns, protests before and during games at home and away. It has become very difficult. But again Wenger must try to succeed against this backdrop. 
Maybe the next week or so is another acid test. How bad will it get? The depth of feeling. Arsenal are moving towards Wenger, but it is not done, not signed and maybe there is a tiny bit of wriggle room. A Wenger Out banner at The Hawthorns (Photo: AFP) 
And, almost most importantly, this should take away the uncertainty which has, without doubt, left players wondering and in a state of limbo. 
Wenger retains the support and respect of the dressing room, to such an extent that a player like Hector Bellerin made it clear he would reconsider his future if Wenger went. Yes, he has his faults, but he has been a mentor for young players through generations. 
And if the players think the manager is going, they tend to ease off, performances drop and if they know Wenger is staying then the hope will be that they pull together during the run-in. 
It is something which blighted even the great Sir Alex Ferguson who admitted his biggest mistake while in charge of Manchester United. Ferguson went back on his decision to retire (Photo: Harold Cunningham/AFP/Getty) 
Twelve years before his retirement in 2013, Fergie shocked the football world by claiming it was going to be his last ever season. 
Fergie recalled: “I think a lot of them had put their tools away. They thought, “Oh, the manager’s leaving”, but when I changed my mind in the January, I started thinking about United again and how we could get back on top.” 
That is what Arsenal will be hoping will be the outcome for Wenger and his players not just in the next few weeks but for however long he stays in charge. poll loading Will Arsene Wenger still be at Arsenal next season? 0+ VOTES SO FAR
